inlineContent.text: Many smart contracts rely on contextual data to execute their operations effectively. This data can include input payments, the caller’s address, the current time, the balance of a specific account, or even the contract owner.
The SpaceKit framework provides an intuitive way to retrieve all of this information using the
and
objects.
Start by defining the contract’s basic structure.
Track the specific token type to be deposited. Store its identifier in the contract’s storage using a
variable.
Note: This variable will be initialized later in the contract’s
function.
Create a
variable to keep track of the total amount deposited by each user.
Reminder: Numeric storage variables default to 0.
Add an initializer to the contract, which accepts the token identifier as a parameter.
Define the
endpoint for the contract.
Use the
property to retrieve the address of the user making the deposit.
Note: The
object also allows retrieval of multi payments, non-fungible tokens, and EGLD payments.
Access the single fungible token payment using
. If the transaction doesn’t include exactly one fungible token payment, the transaction will fail.
Verify the payment by comparing the token identifier with the stored value.
Add the payment amount to the storage mapping for the caller’s address.
In this section, you will create a simple smart contract that allows users to deposit a specified fungible token. The contract will track the total amount of tokens deposited by each user.
In this section, you will improve the previous contract by adding constraints: each address can deposit only once every 24 hours, and deposits must not exceed 10% of the user’s token balance.
Start by using the contract from the previous section.
Define a global constant representing the number of seconds in a day.
Add a mapping to store the last deposit time for each user.
In the
endpoint, retrieve the current timestamp using
Note: The timestamp is the number of seconds since January 1, 1970.
Retrieve the last deposit time for the caller from the storage.
Compute the next allowed deposit time by adding one day’s worth of seconds to the last deposit time.
Ensure the caller is allowed to deposit now.
If the deposit isn’t allowed yet, calculate the remaining time before the next deposit is permitted.
Tip: You can interpolate buffers, addresses, and numeric types into string literals when creating error messages.
Use the calculated time to return an error message with the remaining time.
Retrieve the caller’s token balance using
Tip: If no token identifier is provided, the EGLD balance is returned.
Note: Be cautious when performing integer division as any fractional part is discarded.
Calculate the maximum allowable deposit by dividing the caller’s token balance by 10.
Ensure the deposit amount does not exceed the maximum allowable limit.
Update the last deposit time for the caller to the current block timestamp.

abstract.text: Smart contracts can interact not only with users but also with other smart contracts. This enables more advanced protocols by leveraging existing ones. For example, you could integrate a decentralized exchange directly into your contract to perform token swaps. Decentralized applications often involve multiple contracts, each with a dedicated role, working together to achieve complex functionality—similar to microservices in backend systems.
SpaceKit provides types that allow you to leverage the full potential of the SpaceVM.

Blockchain platforms using SpaceVM enable seamless execution within a sharded environment. Sharding divides a blockchain’s global state and validation workload into smaller, manageable units known as shards. This method enhances scalability without compromising decentralization, allowing nodes to operate without significant computational resources.

doc://SpaceKit/tutorials/SpaceKit/Unders.title: Issuing a Semi-Fungible Token from Your Contract

abstract.text: Learn about the ESDT standard used in the SpaceKit framework, a token model that supports fungible tokens, non-fungible tokens (NFTs), semi-fungible tokens, and meta-esdt tokens.
The SpaceKit framework uses a token standard called ESDT. This standard defines four types of tokens: fungible, non-fungible (NFT), semi-fungible, and meta-esdt.
Before writing your first smart contract with SpaceKit, ensure you have the necessary tools installed.
SpaceKit provides types that allow you to leverage the full potential of the SpaceVM.
Each time a smart contract is invoked, it runs a single operation. The contract is temporarily loaded into the SpaceVM memory, the operation is executed, and then the contract is removed from memory.

Blockchain platforms using SpaceVM enable seamless execution within a sharded environment. Sharding divides a blockchain’s global state and validation workload into smaller, manageable units known as shards. This method enhances scalability without compromising decentralization, allowing nodes to operate without significant computational resources.
Learn about the ESDT standard used in the SpaceKit framework, a token model that supports fungible tokens, non-fungible tokens (NFTs), semi-fungible tokens, and meta-esdt tokens.
The SpaceKit framework uses a token standard called ESDT. This standard defines four types of tokens: fungible, non-fungible (NFT), semi-fungible, and meta-esdt.

doc://SpaceKit/tutorials/SpaceKit/Unders.title: Issuing a Fungible Token from Your Contract

abstract.text: Non-fungible tokens (NFTs) are unique digital assets that cannot be interchanged. Each NFT is associated with a unique identifier, known as a nonce. You can think of it like an airline ticket—each ticket is assigned to a specific passenger, with individual preferences and details.

The ESDT standard enables embedding custom data within non-fungible tokens, allowing developers to extend the functionality of their smart contracts. This additional data, referred to as “attributes,” is tied to the token and transfers along with it between wallets.

The ESDT standard enables embedding custom data within non-fungible tokens, allowing developers to extend the functionality of their smart contracts. This additional data, referred to as “attributes,” is tied to the token and transfers along with it between wallets.

The ESDT standard enables embedding custom data within non-fungible tokens, allowing developers to extend the functionality of their smart contracts. This additional data, referred to as “attributes,” is tied to the token and transfers along with it between wallets.

content: smartContractError(message: "Not allowed to deposit yet. Please wait \(secondsRemaining) seconds.")

abstract.text: In this tutorial, you’ll create a simple smart contract that manages a counter. Users can increment or decrement the counter, and the changes are persisted across contract executions.
Discover how SpaceKit simplifies blockchain development using Swift. Dive into the world of Web3 with ease and efficiency.
In this tutorial, you’ll create a simple smart contract that manages a counter. Users can increment or decrement the counter, and the changes are persisted across contract executions.

Fungible tokens function similarly to traditional currencies, making them the simplest type of token to work with.
